awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Calibrating the end-Ediacaran Extinction with U-Pb Geochronology & Chemostratigraphy at a New Precambrian-Cambrian Boundary Site in Namibia & South Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
The first appearance and rapid diversification of complex, multicellular animals at the dawn of the Cambrian (~540 million years ago) is conceivably the single most significant episode in the evolution of life on Earth, as it laid out the initial blueprints for the vast majority of life forms that exist today. Understanding the driving mechanisms of the Cambrian 'explosion' have been challenging because life forms that dominated the preceding period, the Ediacaran, have a sparse fossil record. In addition, the marine sedimentary rocks that preserve the Ediacaran-Cambrian transition are now scattered across the continents, hampering an unequivocal reconstruction of life and the environment at this crucial junction of the geologic history. This study focuses on key outcrops of the Ediacaran-Cambrian marine deposits with spectacular fossils and high potential for precise isotopic dating in a previously unexplored region near the Namibia-South Africa border. The results will provide new insights into the rates of paleoenvironmental and ocean chemical change during this critical time interval. In addition to public presentations and scholarly publications, a comprehensive program of educational, training, and outreach activities are planned.

This project employs an integrated program of field mapping, sedimentology, chemo- and bio-stratigraphy on newly discovered marine carbonate-rich and fossiliferous Ediacaran-Cambrian sections on either side of the Orange River in Namibia and South Africa with abundant intercalated ash beds suitable to U-Pb geochronology. It will provide a high-resolution record that will help to unravel the mode and rates of biotic and coeval environmental changes at the close of the Proterozoic. The results will be a major step forward in testing the hypothesis that there were globally synchronous environmental perturbations that were genetically associated with biotic turnover across the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary, and will lead to a better understanding of the driving mechanisms of the Cambrian radiation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has resulted in an integrated dataset that establishes an area on the border between Namibia and South Africa as a key new site to study the Ediacaran?Cambrian transition, one of Earth?s most important geobiological transitions since the advent of photosynthesis. Under this project, the research team completed two field seasons in South Africa and Namibia to collect field observations and samples to test the hypothesis that there was a globally synchronous perturbation to the ocean-atmosphere at the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary when modern animal phyla diversified. The significant results of this project include: (1) the first detailed geologic map of a new Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary locality, (2) new stable isotope measurements integrated with the stratigraphy from the region, (3) new high resolution U-Pb geochronology data from ash beds allowing for calibration of the sedimentary strata, and (4) what is to date, the highest resolution Bayesian age-depth model for any Ediacaran?Cambrian boundary locality globally, allowing for precise calibration of the oceanic geochemical and paleontological records at this site. One impact of this work is that the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary could be several million years younger than previously thought. If this is correct, it would compress the earliest stages of the Cambrian biological radiation of animals, resulting in a radical recalibration of the tempo of evolution and further shortening the fuse of the Cambrian explosion of biological diversity. Additionally, results from this work have been important for an International Continental Scientific Drilling Program (ICDP) project that is drilling the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary on three separate paleocontinents, including Namibia. One of the drill sites was chosen at the study site as a direct result from this project. The resulting core was recently transported to the ICDP core shed in Germany, and an international team of geoscientists and students are now actively working on this core. The combined results from this project have been published in student-led peer reviewed journal articles and have been disseminated through presentations at professional conferences.

A number of students at different educational levels were trained in various capacities as part of this project. Three Two PhD students gained significant experiences in sedimentary geology, geologic mapping, geochronology, and stable isotope geochemistry. One planetary PhD student who is working on Mars sedimentology gained experience doing terrestrial analog work. Another PhD student is working on S isotope geochemistry gained experience in geologic mapping, measuring stratigraphic sections, and collecting sedimentary rocks for subsequent analyses. Four undergraduate students gained training in the lab. At least one of these students has gone onto graduate school, and is now pursuing a PhD at Stanford University. Two Baltimore City high school students gained lab training as part of this project. Both students have graduated from high school and are considering majoring in geology in college.

 


Last Modified: 02/10/2023
Modified by: Emily Smith
